posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
How does your team primarily write commands?  

Inline definitions/factory functions (e.g., `run`, `runOnce`) or explicit subclasses of `Command`.  

This poll tracks how you primarily interact with the Command-based framework this year.  

Recall that commands can be created in two ways:  
1. By writing a subclass of `Command` with overrides for lifecycle methods (`initialize`, `execute`, `isFinished`, `end`).  
2. By passing your code as a callback to a factory function or `Command` subclass constructor.  

Past polls indicate significant use of legacy `Command` subclassing, though modern trends favor functional approaches.  

Please share your primary interaction with the Command-based framework this year.

posts.name: Josh P
posts.cooked:
We started mostly inline, utilizing the `registerXXXX` methods in the RobotContainer class (link provided). However, due to the need for named commands for Pathplanner integration, each student developed explicit command classes, which left an impression on them as they were occupied with volunteer work during development.

This year, our subsystems were primarily finite-state machines or involved migrating control loops to setpoints, resulting in simple state-changing commands managed within subsystem periodic methods, with most control logic handled internally.

I aim to seek their insights on their design decisions and gather feedback to improve future implementations.

Previously, we typically created explicit command classes, but this year, we chose to keep things more inline for commands.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: Our were mostly inline, with a couple explicit classes for something more complicated (like auto-align to a reef pole).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Noah Zemlin
posts.cooked: This year, our split mirrored yours, depending on whoever was writing the code. Last year, we used 100% explicit subclasses. Next year, I aim to guide programmers toward nearly 100% inline or factory functions, except for highly complex commands involving multiple operations like combined auto-align and scoring. Reducing the 1,000 different XYZCommand.java files improved code readability and traceability significantly.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked: We use inline for most of our really basic commands but often put a lot of logic into our commands making them unwieldy. Despite this our default is still subclasses. We also appreciate the convenience of referencing commands in command groups though I'm not sure how we'd compose command groups of anonymous inner classes.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: We started using command factories this year, thanks to @bovlb, for nearly all our commands, barring a few long sequences that had their own files. This approach saved a significant amount of time compared to writing out entire files, and it simplified and made the process cleaner when binding commands to buttons. Our robot this year didn't require a state machine-style control; instead, it could operate based on a few preset sequences, which makes sense since command factories are particularly effective in such scenarios. Excitedly, we plan to adopt this new method moving forward.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I'm not sure how we'd compose command groups of anonymous inner classes.

Factory methods!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version:

Our students found that small files made tracking complex parallel/sequential tasks easier. Another minor issue was wanting to log the active command; it requires a name, and the collections must log correctly as well.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We employed purely factory methods this year. While they functioned effectively in most cases, there is a need to reintroduce an organizational structure instead of relying on subclass approaches. For example, all our multiSubsystem factories were integrated into the Autos class alongside other utility functions for selecting scoring operations. Certain factories required class-scoped objects, such as Trapezoid Profiles or SwerveRequests, which were positioned adjacent to their respective factory methods. Although well-commented code helps maintain organization, the Drivebase class ended up containing intricate drivebase-specific command logic, making the Autos class difficult to navigate due to its complexity.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked:
This is my first year running programming for our team. We primarily used inline commands up until the week before competition because we were building subsystems on the fly, making testing challenging except for a basic drive function. However, I quickly realized that lacking knowledge in command-based programming caused half of our inline commands not to respond properly. After this realization, we switched to using command classes, which have worked well ever since. Although there are still some complexities to figure out, I find command classes much simpler.

Commands.runOnce() is utilized extensively in our codebase. My approach to answering questions has evolved over the season, but for now, I prefer handling individual commands inline due to the numerous leftovers in the code.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked:
To organize your code effectively for WPILib, follow this structured approach:

1. **Identify Method Dependencies**: Determine which methods require interaction between multiple subsystems.

2. **Design Global Methods When Necessary**: 
   - Create dedicated global methods for commands needing interactions across subsystems. These methods can orchestrate calls without polluting namespaces.
   - Consider using helper methods or abstract classes to manage combined interactions efficiently.

3. **Keep Core Responsibilities Local**: Place methods handling single subsystem operations within their respective subsystem classes for better encapsulation.

4. **Maintain Modularity**: Follow WPILib's recommendation for modular design, ensuring each subsystem focuses on its core functionality.

By implementing these steps, you'll achieve a balanced, maintainable code structure that respects both subsystem independence and necessary interdependencies.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Subsystems should expose their contracts as command factories in subsystem scope. Composite commands using multiple subsystems can be defined in RobotContainer, or else in some command factory helper class into which you inject the subsystems.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked:
As explained in the earlier threads, WPILib has been moving towards a more-functional/less OO-driven architecture for several years now—but as past polls have shown, legacy subclass interactions are still quite popular.

Is there a good example of this? We’ve been pretty unhappy with the heavy OO architecture and have slowly been getting more functional with lots of suppliers and light state machines controlled by commands. But it’s hard to break old habits, and I haven’t seen a good example of this; only talk that "triggers are the new way you should be doing most things."

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The RapidReactCommandBot example is the most architecturally up-to-date of the official examples at the moment. I know some people are working on docs improvements this summer, so this may change.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: We only received commands from subsystem files, but everything functioned through an overarching “superstructure” class (finite state machine), which heavily relied on Triggers to clearly define state transitions. Shoutout to 8033 for this effective state machine approach—I wholeheartedly endorse it.

Our programmers and I love inline commands. Our robot, built in 24 months, didn’t need a state machine this year, so everything could be programmed as sequences. They also used them in our NamedCommands for auto routines.

Our programmers typically create basic commands as subclasses, like RunIntake or ShootCoral, and then use the Command Factories API to chain them together like a sequence.

For example:
joystick.x()
    .onTrue(new IntakeAndPivot(collector, 0.7))
    .until(() -> !collector.hasAlgae())
    .andThen(new PivotBack(collector));

However, it made our RobotContainer class quite large and clunky to read, and it got really weird when our lead programmer tried to code an auto-align to the reef, so we put the complex stuff in its own Command class instead.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: We’ve transitioned to a trigger-based architecture this year, simplifying operations by centralizing all actions and measurements into triggers. These triggers replace traditional commands, streamlining workflows through a single file that encapsulates every action and sensor reading. Inspired by SpectrumLib, our setup uses triggers to manage commands, ensuring seamless interaction with subsystems. For further insight, watch Allen’s video here: [video link].

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

I recommend use of the `withName` decorator. You should be using this liberally inside your command factories and anywhere you are compounding commands.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: As I understand it, neither the inline factories nor the WPILib collections support the desired functionality. Commands.idle().withName("Busywork") achieves this. Placing this at the end of your composition is recommended. We implemented a Trigger+Command factory interface last year, which streamlined operations compared to using void methods. Simple commands benefit from reduced syntax, while complex tasks like trapezoidal profiles were managed efficiently through a single point of control. A significant challenge was defining clear command termination; avoiding default shutdowns led us to create conditions or fallback factories. Unfortunately, our attempt to automate command state management using a robust state machine fell short, prompting it to become our summer project.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: Have you checked out the 8033 approach? I really liked it and found it really easy to implement. You can check out their code or ours for examples for this year.
